Tolkien]].]] {{Quote|Before long the ''Via Maxima'' was packed with an unceasing stream of ''Motores'' crawling so slowly from halt to halt that a man could (like an animal) walk its whole length and back to find a ‘mounted’ friend only 10 yards further on his way, while the horn of his ''Motor'' trumpeted in vexation.|Excerpt from the story{{webcite|author=[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/authors/l/la-le/Leith/ Sam Leith]|articleurl=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/books/what-to-read/best-novels-to-read-october/|articlename=The endless ‘unearthing’ of Tolkien’s archive needs to stop|dated=3 October 2025|website=Telegraph|accessed=4 October 2025|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20251003234636/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/books/what-to-read/best-novels-to-read-october/|archivename=The endless ‘unearthing’ of Tolkien’s archive needs to stop|archivedate=3 October 2025}} ([https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/the-endless-unearthing-of-tolkien-s-archive-needs-to-stop/ar-AA1NNv3X?ocid=socialshare second source])}} '''''The End of Bovadium''''' (author's title)[[Letter to Rayner Unwin (2 December 1968)]], quoted in {{CG|C}}, p. 737 (entry "2 December 1968") or '''''The Bovadium Fragments''''' is a short story by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] written between mid 1957{{webcite|author=[https://www.tolkienguide.com/profile/1 Urulókë], [https://www.tolkienguide.com/profile/4446 onthetrail], [https://www.tolkienguide.com/profile/10 Trotter], and [https://www.tolkienguide.com/profile/5058 Mr. Underhill]|articleurl=https://www.tolkienguide.com/modules/newbb/viewtopic.php?topic_id=6867|articlename=The Bovadium Fragments: TolkienGuide review|dated=3 October 2025|website=Guide|accessed=4 October 2025|archiveurl=|archivename=|archivedate=}} and early 1960.{{CG|RG}}, "Environment", pp. 255-6 ("The Machine") According to [[Richard Ovenden]], the [[Bodleian Library]]'s librarian, ''The Bovadium Fragments'' "is about a scholar in the future looking at evidence of a society that is now lost" due to worshipping automobiles.{{webcite|author=[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/authors/d/da-de/dalya-alberge/ Dalya Alberge]|articleurl=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2025/05/30/morris-motors-boss-may-inspired-tolkien-villain/|articlename=Morris Motors boss may have inspired Tolkien villain|dated=30 May 2025|website=Telegraph|accessed=30 May 2025|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20250720042338/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2025/05/30/morris-motors-boss-may-inspired-tolkien-villain/|archivename=Morris Motors boss may have inspired Tolkien villain|archivedate=20 July 2025}} [[John Garth]] describes ''The Bovadium Fragments'' as "a satire on modernity, without adventures", taking place in "a post-apocalyptic future when civilisation as we know it has collapsed" because of cars.{{webcite|author=[[John Garth]]|articleurl=https://www.thetimes.com/culture/books/article/lord-of-the-ring-road-jrr-tolkiens-war-against-the-motor-car-ssv8g3qtl|articlename=Lord of the ring road — JRR Tolkien’s war against the motor car|dated=3 October 2025|website=[https://www.thetimes.com/ The Sunday Times]|accessed=4 October 2025|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20251005022245/https://www.thetimes.com/culture/books/article/lord-of-the-ring-road-jrr-tolkiens-war-against-the-motor-car-ssv8g3qtl|archivename=Lord of the ring road — JRR Tolkien’s war against the motor car|archivedate=5 October 2025}} ==Synopsis== ===Foreword=== The story begins with a Foreword by [[Doctor Sarevelk]] discussing "[[Bovadium|a site]] of historical" importance "found at ''[[Vâsti|Vasti]]''" "on the borders of the [[Southern Region]]",{{TBF|Foreword}} and two" "equally dead and obscure" languages that are referred to as "''[[Latin|A]]'' and ''[[Modern English|B]]''". While Language B has been "almost entirely deciphered" at the time of the story using "the [[Rotzopny]]–[[Dwarf]] treatment", language A is not. In the second part of the Foreword, [[Dr. Gums]] summarizes the three fragments of the story proper and explains his method of translating them in a smug way. ===Fragment I=== The first of the three fragments discussed is "a chronicle or legend in language A" which Fragment II, according to Dr. Gums, is a translation of.{{TBF|I}} ===Fragment II=== The second of the three fragments discussed is a translation and expanded version of Fragment I,{{TBF|II}} describing the takeover of Bovadium by the Motores. ===Fragment III=== The third of the three fragments discussed is a text in Language B with inserts from language A that describes the aftermath of the end of Bovadium.{{TBF|III}} ===Postscript by the Editor=== The story concludes with a fictitious Postscript by Dr. Gums.{{TBF|Postscript}} ==Other Texts of Fragment II== Following the story, [[Christopher Tolkien]] describes two additional texts of Fragment II both entitled ''[[Domine defende nos contra hos Motores bos!]]''. The first is a poem "in thirty-one octosyllabic couplets" while the second is a Latin text which Christopher Tolkien translated.{{TBF|Other}} ==Background== Sometime between mid [[1957]] and early [[1960]],{{CG|C}}, p. 563 (entry "25 October 1960") Tolkien wrote a short "satire"[[Clyde S. Kilby]], ''[[Tolkien and The Silmarillion|Tolkien & The Silmarillion]]'', II. "Summer with Tolkien", "Some Notes on “Smith of Wootton Major”", p. 36 entitled ''The End of Bovadium'' or ''The Bovadium Fragments''.{{B|IV}}, Chapter VI: The Storyteller, p. 163 (footnote) Tolkien initially wrote it "for his own amusement" as "a private academic jest" to gently satirize "pomposities of archaeologists" and the "hideousness of college crockery", being inspired by [[Wikipedia:Alfred Denis Godley|A.D. Godley]]'s ''[[Wikipedia:The Motor Bus|Motor Bus]]'' comic poem and a "[[The Origin of Bovadium|recrudescence of the debate]] about [[Oxford]] roads".{{TBF|PN}} On [[25 October]] [[1960]], Tolkien sought (through his secretary [[Elisabeth Lumsden]]) to publish what is believed to be this writing (since it was described as "a sort of satirical fantasy") in the magazine ''[[Wikipedia:Time and Tide (magazine)|Time and Tide]]''.Tolkien had earlier published his poem ''[[Imram]]'' in the magazine [[Time and Tide (3 December 1955)|''Time and Tide'' (3 December 1955)]]. Cf. {{SD|2}}, p. 296. In a [[Letter 231a|letter]] to [[Joan Anne Tolkien]] in [[November]] [[1961]], Tolkien mentioned the suffering of Oxford "from the ravages of the machine-worshippers".{{LE|231a}}, p. 438 On [[24 August]] [[1966]], Tolkien lent [[Rayner Unwin]] the manuscript,{{CG|C}}, p. 673 (entry "24 August 1966") who wrote to Tolkien already the next day, thinking that he "should publish it in the [[Oxford Magazine]]".{{CG|C}}, p. 673 (entry "25 August 1966") Later, around the same time, [[Clyde S. Kilby]] was also given a copy, being asked if the piece was worthy of publication. On or before [[29 November]] [[1968]], ''The End of Bovadium'' was included in a list of unpublished works that Tolkien had his secretary, [[Joy Hill]], compile.{{CG|C}}, p. 736 (entry "29 November 1968") In a letter to Rayner Unwin on [[2 December]], Tolkien commented that, though ''The End of Bovadium'' was on the list of unpublished works, he had "no intention of publishing" it to keep it from preventing him from working on his "[[The Silmarillion|proper work]]". After Tolkien's death in [[1973]], Clyde S. Kilby would later recall the story in April [[1976]]:{{blockquote|Though the reading of ''The Silmarillon'' was proving about as much as I could handle during that summer of 1966, Tolkien from time to time handed me other shorter pieces and asked me about their publishability. One was called “The Bovadium Fragments,” a satire written long before and having as its main point the worship of the ''Motores'', i.e., automobiles, and the traffic jams blocking the roads in and around Oxford. It was full of the inventiveness to be expected of Tolkien. Some of the characters are [[Rotzopny]], [[Dr. Gums]], and [[Doctor Sarevelk|Sarevelk]]. I judged that it had two elements that would make it unpublishable. One was the more than liberal use of Latin, and the other the probability that a reader's eye would focus on its playfulness rather than its serious implications. Actually it was an early comment on the commercialization of our world.}} A few more details about the contents were provided in [[Humphrey Carpenter]]'s summary dating from [[1977]], saying that:{{blockquote|‘The Bovadium Fragments’ (perhaps composed early in the nineteen-sixties) is a parable of the destruction of [[Oxford]] (''Bovadium'') by the ''motores'' manufactured by the ''[[Daemon]]'' of ''[[Vaccipratum]]'' (a reference to [[Wikipedia:Lord Nuffield|Lord Nuffield]] and his motor-works at Cowley) which blocks the streets, asphyxiate the inhabitants, and finally explode.}} Carpenter also notes that the theme of "motor transport" connects the story to ''[[Mr. Bliss]]''. In a footnote to [[Letter 181]] in ''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'', Carpenter speculated that Tolkien's statement that "the present design of destroying Oxford in order to accommodate motor-cars"{{L|181}}, pp. 232-7 is "a reference to the proposal for a ‘relief’ road through Christ Church Meadow".{{L|181}}, "Notes", [[Letter 181|181]], p. 446 (note 2) The writing was given to the [[Bodleian Library]] by [[The Tolkien Trust]] in [[1985]],{{webcite|author=[https://www.tolkienguide.com/profile/4446 onthetrail]|articleurl=https://www.tolkienguide.com/guide/books/111|articlename=The Bovadium Fragments: Together with ‘The Origin of Bovadium’ by Richard Ovenden O.B.|dated=11 September 2025|website=Guide|accessed=2 October 2025|archiveurl=|archivename=|archivedate=}} where it was kept in the Department of Western Manuscripts (Mss. Tolkien, Series A, folder A62, pages 38–91).{{HH|X}}, Endnotes, p. 462 (footnote to Endnote 11) It is likely that the manuscript consists of 53 pages.{{webcite|author=[https://www.jrrvf.com/fluxbb/viewtopic.php?id=6822 Sosryko]|articleurl=https://www.jrrvf.com/fluxbb/viewtopic.php?pid=79613#p79613|articlename=La Machine ou la nécessité de raser le monde réel (French)|dated=15 May 2009|website=[http://www.jrrvf.com JRRVF - Tolkien en Version Française - Les nouveautés sur le site, l’actualité tolkienienne sur le Web]|accessed=5 May 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20250630042303/https://www.jrrvf.com/fluxbb/viewtopic.php?pid=79613#p79613|archivename=La Machine ou la nécessité de raser le monde réel (French)|archivedate=30 April 2025}} The manuscript was reassigned in [[2003]] from "MS Tolkien A 62"[[Oronzo Cilli]], ''[[Tolkien's Library: An Annotated Checklist|Tolkien's Library: An Annotated Checklist - Second Edition Revised and Expanded]]'', "Bibliography", "Tolkien Papers (Bodleian Library, Oxford)" to "MS. Tolkien B 62" alongside ''[[Sellic Spell]]'', ''[[The New Shadow]]'', and other notes, thereby making it not available for research. In [[1992]], ''The Bovadium Fragments'' was mentioned in Judith Priestman's ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Life and Legend]]'' in the entry about Tolkien's copy of A.D. Godley's ''Motor Bus'' poem.Judith Priestman, ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Life and Legend]]'', "Last Years", p. 86 (entry for "248 A.D. Godley's ‘Motor Bus’") Tolkien kept "the poem with his typescript of" ''The End of Bovadium''.[[Oronzo Cilli]], ''[[Tolkien's Library: An Annotated Checklist|Tolkien's Library: An Annotated Checklist - Second Edition Revised and Expanded]]'', "Section A - Primary Sources", p. 107 (item 775) On [[8 September]] of [[2010]], [[John D. Rateliff]] stated on his blog that its "a pity" Tolkien decided "against publishing" ''The Bovadium Fragments'' "since an anti-car environmental message from Tolkien published in the mid-sixties might have done some good".{{webcite|author=[[John D. Rateliff]]|articleurl=https://sacnoths.blogspot.com/2010/09/tolkien-on-cars.html?m=1|articlename=Tolkien on Cars|dated=8 September 2010|website=Sac|accessed=30 June 2025|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20250823082813/http://sacnoths.blogspot.com/2010/09/tolkien-on-cars.html|archivename=Tolkien on Cars|archivedate=23 August 2025}}

October]].{{webcite|author=[https://www.tolkienguide.com/profile/10 Trotter]|articleurl=https://www.tolkienguide.com/modules/newbb/viewtopic.php?topic_id=6704|articlename=The Bovadium Fragments: June 2025|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20250623032252/https://lingwe.blogspot.com/2025/05/first-mention-of-bovadium-fragments.html|archivename=First mention of The Bovadium 2025|website=Lingwe|accessed=30 June 2025|archiveurl=|archivename=|archivedate=}} On [[30 May]], the story was described by [[Chris Smith]], [[HarperCollins]]'s Tolkien Publishing Director,{{webcite|author=[[Shaun Gunner]]|articleurl=https://www.tolkiensociety.org/2025/06/new-tolkien-book-the-bovadium-fragments/|articlename=New Tolkien book – ''The Bovadium Fragments'' – is satire on industrialisation|dated=27 June 2025|website=TS|accessed=3 July 2025|archiveurl=|archivename=|archivedate=}} as:{{blockquote|a sharply satirical account of the perils of allowing car production and machine-worship to take over your town, where things ultimately all go to hell, in a very literal sense.}} On [[27 June]], [[Shaun Gunner]] noted in an article on the website of [[The Tolkien Society]] that ''The End of Bovadium'' is "Tolkien’s comment on industrialisation and environmental concerns" and is similar but different compared to ''Mr. Bliss''. On [[21 July]], Nancy Steinman stated in an article on [[TheOneRing.net]] that ''The End of Bovadium'' reflected "Tolkien’s disdain of industrialism", comparing the story to "[[The Scouring of the Shire]]" chapter in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''.{{webcite|author=[https://www.theonering.net/torwp/author/mithrildesigns/ Nancy "Mithril" Steinman]|articleurl=https://www.theonering.net/torwp/2025/07/21/120581-the-bovadium-fragments-new-tolkien-book-release-later-this-year/|articlename=“The Bovadium Fragments”–New Tolkien Book release later this year|dated=21 July 2025|website=TORN|accessed=27 September 2025|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20251005180901/https://www.theonering.net/torwp/2025/07/21/120581-the-bovadium-fragments-new-tolkien-book-release-later-this-year/|archivename=“The Bovadium Fragments”–New Tolkien Book release later this year|archivedate=5 October 2025}} On [[3 October]], Sam Leith wrote a harsh criticism of the 2025 book on the website of "The Telegraph".
